DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text descriptor of findings related to skin and surrounding structure changes due to breast carcinoma.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit.  Breast carcinoma may affect both females and males.  It is the most common malignant tumor and the leading cause of carcinoma death in women.  Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation.  The widespread use of mammography has contributed in the detection of very early cancerous lesions (less than 2mm in diameter).  The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular).  Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route.  The most common site of lymph node involvment is the axilla.  Breast carcinomas infrequently occur in males (particularly elderly individuals and patients with Klinefelter's syndrome).  The therapy of breat carcinoma includes surgery, radiation therapy, hormonal therapy and chemotherapy, depending on the type and extend of the disease. --2002_Joined in some kind of relationship._Clinical manifestations that can be either objective when observed by a physician, or subjective when perceived by the patient.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Pathological transudate within one or more tissues.(FMA)

Concepts.definition: Accumulation of an excessive amount of fluid in cells or intercellular tissues.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A sac-like closed membranous structure that may be empty or contain fluid or amorphous material.

Concepts.definition: A sac-like closed membranous structure that may be empty or contain fluid or amorphous material.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A disorder characterized by a localized collection of blood, usually clotted, in an organ, space, or tissue, due to a break in the wall of a blood vessel.

Concepts.definition: A disorder characterized by a localized collection of blood, usually clotted, in an organ, space, or tissue, due to a break in the wall of a blood vessel.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The total system of structures outside the lungs that move as a part of breathing; it includes all structures from the skin to the parietal pleura.: The movement of one cell type into an area normally occupied by a different cell type.

Concepts.definition: The total system of structures outside the lungs that move as a part of breathing; it includes all structures from the skin to the parietal pleura.
The movement of one cell type into an area normally occupied by a different cell type.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Muscles of the upper chest. The term may refer to one of two muscles, the pectoralis major and pectoralis minor. The former is a thick muscle in the anterior portion of the chest. Its action involves flexion, medial rotation, and adduction of the humerus. The latter is a thin muscle located beneath the pectoralis major. Its action involves lowering the scapula and raising the ribs.: The movement of one cell type into an area normally occupied by a different cell type.

Concepts.definition: Muscles of the upper chest. The term may refer to one of two muscles, the pectoralis major and pectoralis minor. The former is a thick muscle in the anterior portion of the chest. Its action involves flexion, medial rotation, and adduction of the humerus. The latter is a thin muscle located beneath the pectoralis major. Its action involves lowering the scapula and raising the ribs.
The movement of one cell type into an area normally occupied by a different cell type.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A clinical finding indicating that a lymph node is enlarged. Causes include viral and bacterial infections and cancers that affect the lymph nodes.

Concepts.definition: An enlarged lymph node. Causes include viral and bacterial infections and cancers that affect the lymph nodes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An organ that constitutes the external surface of the body. It consists of the epidermis, dermis, and skin appendages.: The movement of one cell type into an area normally occupied by a different cell type.

Concepts.definition: An organ that constitutes the external surface of the body. It consists of the epidermis, dermis, and skin appendages.
The movement of one cell type into an area normally occupied by a different cell type.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: widely spread; not localized or confined.: An organ that constitutes the external surface of the body.  It consists of the epidermis, dermis, and skin appendages.: The dimension between two surfaces of an object, usually the smallest dimension as opposed to the width or the length: also, viscous consistency.

Concepts.definition: Widely spread; not localized or confined.
An organ that constitutes the external surface of the body. It consists of the epidermis, dermis, and skin appendages.
The dimension between two surfaces of an object, usually the smallest dimension as opposed to the width or the length: also, viscous consistency.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The movement of one cell type into an area normally occupied by a different cell type.: The pigmented projection on the surface of the breast. Ducts that conduct milk from the mammary glands to the surface of the breast exit through the nipple. (from MedTerms Medical Dictionary; medterms.com)

Concepts.definition: The movement of one cell type into an area normally occupied by a different cell type.
The pigmented protuberance on the surface of the breast through which milk is drawn from the breast.
